str:Codelist.com:Name: Transformation
str:Codelist.com:Description: This codelist represents a set of codes identifying the specific transformations or calculations applied to source data to derive new data elements or indicators. A transformation involves a computation with one or more input values (either base variables obtained by observation or derived variables from prior transformations) that results in a single output value (the value of a new derived variable).

str:Code.com:Name: 1 digit level, percent
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to a percentage value that is expressed with one digit after the decimal point, providing a level of precision to the tenths place (e.g., 23.4%).

str:Code.com:Name: 12-month moving average
str:Code.com:Description: A moving average is a method for smoothing time series by averaging (with or without weights) a fixed number of consecutive terms, e.g. 12-month periods.

str:Code.com:Name: 12-month rolling beta
str:Code.com:Description: A 12-month rolling beta is a statistical measure that shows the volatility of an investment compared to a benchmark index (like the S&P 500) over a 12-month period. This calculation is done continuously, with each new month's data replacing the oldest month in the calculation, creating a "rolling" effect. One unit is equivalent to one standard deviation of the standardized variable.

str:Code.com:Name: 12-period cumulated sum
str:Code.com:Description: A 12-period cumulated sum is a calculation that adds up a set of values over a consecutive 12-period window. This could be 12 months, 12 quarters, or any other relevant time frame.

str:Code.com:Name: 12-period moving average
str:Code.com:Description: The 12-period moving average is a method to smooth a time series by calculating the average of 12 consecutive periods, including the one associated with the observation under consideration. It is used to identify trends over time by reducing the impact of short-term fluctuations.

str:Code.com:Name: 16-period cumulated sum
str:Code.com:Description: A 16-period cumulated sum is a calculation that adds up a set of values over a consecutive 16-period window. This could be 16 months, 16 quarters.

str:Code.com:Name: 1st quartile
str:Code.com:Description: Median of the lower half of the data set, dividing the lowest 25% from the remaining 75%.

str:Code.com:Name: 2 digit level, percent
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to a percentage value that is expressed with two digits after the decimal point, providing a level of precision to the hundredths place (e.g., 56.78%).

str:Code.com:Name: 2nd quartile
str:Code.com:Description: Median value in a dataset, dividing it into two halves.

str:Code.com:Name: 3-period cumulated sum
str:Code.com:Description: A 3-period cumulated sum is a calculation that adds up a set of values over a consecutive 3-period window. This could be 3 months, 3 quarters, or any other relevant time frame.

str:Code.com:Name: 3-period moving average
str:Code.com:Description: The 3-period moving average is a method to smooth a time series by calculating the average of 3 consecutive periods, including the one associated with the observation under consideration. It is used to identify trends over time by reducing the impact of short-term fluctuations.

str:Code.com:Name: 3rd quartile
str:Code.com:Description: Median of the upper half of the data set, dividing the upper 25% from the remaining 75%.

str:Code.com:Name: 4-period cumulated sum
str:Code.com:Description: A 4-period cumulated sum is a calculation that adds up a set of values over a consecutive 4-period window. This could be 4 months, 4 quarters.

str:Code.com:Name: 4-period moving average
str:Code.com:Description: The 4-period moving average is a method to smooth a time series by calculating the average of 4 consecutive periods, including the one associated with the observation under consideration. It is used to identify trends over time by reducing the impact of short-term fluctuations.

str:Code.com:Name: Weighted index, adjusted by relative consumper prices, 6-month rolling monthly squared change.
str:Code.com:Description: Measures the volatility of a data series by calculating the squared difference between each month's value and the previous month's value, averaged over a rolling 6-month window. One unit is equivalent to one standard deviation of the standardized variable.

str:Code.com:Name: 6-period cumulated sum
str:Code.com:Description: The total sum of a data set over a rolling 6-period window.

str:Code.com:Name: 6-period moving average
str:Code.com:Description: The 6-period moving average is a method to smooth a time series by calculating the average of 6 consecutive periods, including the one associated with the observation under consideration. It is used to identify trends over time by reducing the impact of short-term fluctuations.

str:Code.com:Name: 99%, Battery Grade
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to a material or substance that has a purity level of 99% and is suitable for use in batteries. The term "Battery Grade" indicates that the material meets the specific quality and performance requirements for battery applications, such as electrochemical stability, high energy density, and long cycle life.

str:Code.com:Name: 99.2%, Coarse particle
str:Code.com:Description: This likely refers to a material with a specific particle size distribution where 99.2% of the particles are larger than a certain size threshold, indicating a coarse or granular material. The exact size threshold would depend on the context and the specific material being described.

str:Code.com:Name: Adjusted using IMF accounting records
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to data that has been modified or corrected using the accounting records maintained by the International Monetary Fund (IMF). These adjustments are typically made to ensure consistency and accuracy in international financial statistics, particularly for balance of payments data and other macroeconomic indicators. The IMF's accounting records provide a standardized framework for recording and reporting economic transactions between countries, and using these records helps ensure comparability and reliability of data across different nations.

str:Code.com:Name: Aggregate
str:Code.com:Description: Combining individual data points into a single number or summary.

str:Code.com:Name: Aggregate weighted by GDP
str:Code.com:Description: A combined value (e.g., economic output, stock market index, or other indicator) that is calculated by weighting the individual components' values by their respective shares of GDP.

str:Code.com:Name: Aggregate weighted by GDP, percent change
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the change in the combined value of a set of items (the aggregate), where each item's contribution to the total is weighted by its share of GDP.

str:Code.com:Name: Aggregated using market exchange rate based weights, percent change
str:Code.com:Description: An aggregate measure using market exchange rate-based weights and percent change is a calculation that shows the overall change in value of a group of currencies over a specific period. This calculation takes into account both the changes in the individual exchange rates of the currencies and the relative importance of each currency in the group.

str:Code.com:Name: Aggregation weight
str:Code.com:Description: An aggregation weight is a numerical value that is assigned to an individual data point or a group of data points to represent its relative importance or contribution within a larger dataset. Aggregation weights are used to combine or "aggregate" data from different sources or groups to create a single summary statistic or measure.

str:Code.com:Name: Annual levels
str:Code.com:Description: Annual levels refer to data that is collected, analyzed, or reported on a yearly basis.

str:Code.com:Name: Annual rate of change corrected for the effect of methodological changes where applicable
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to a calculation of how much a specific metric or indicator has changed over a year, taking into account any adjustments made to the way the data was collected or calculated. When methodological changes occur, adjustments are made to the data to ensure that the annual rate of change accurately reflects the underlying trend, rather than being influenced by changes in methodology.

str:Code.com:Name: Annualized
str:Code.com:Description: The process of converting a rate of any length of time into its equivalent annual rate for standardized comparison.

str:Code.com:Name: Annualized percent change
str:Code.com:Description: A specific type of annualized rate that expresses the percentage change of a quantity as if it had occurred consistently over a year.

str:Code.com:Name: Assets to gross domestic product (GDP)
str:Code.com:Description: This ratio can refer to different types of assets, such as total financial assets, total assets of the banking sector, or assets of a specific company or sector. It measures the size of these assets relative to the country's GDP.

str:Code.com:Name: Assets to total financial assets
str:Code.com:Description: This ratio looks at the composition of a specific entity's assets (e.g., company, bank, individual) and measures the proportion that is made up of financial assets (such as cash, stocks, bonds, loans receivable).

str:Code.com:Name: Assets to total financial system assets
str:Code.com:Description: This ratio compares an entity's total assets to the aggregate assets of the entire financial system (including all banks, insurance companies, investment funds, etc.) in a country or region.

str:Code.com:Name: Average of percent change
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the arithmetic mean of several percentage changes over a given time frame. It's calculated by summing up the individual percentage changes and dividing by the number of changes.

str:Code.com:Name: Average since 1999
str:Code.com:Description: The arithmetic mean (average) value of a specific data series or indicator calculated over the period from 1999 to the present time.

str:Code.com:Name: Average, period-over-period
str:Code.com:Description: This is a method of comparing a specific metric in one time period to the same metric in a comparable previous time period.

str:Code.com:Name: Bases of recording
str:Code.com:Description: Bases of Recording refers to the timing of when transactions are recognized and recorded in the accounting books.

str:Code.com:Name: By line item
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to a method of organizing or presenting data where each individual item or category is listed separately, allowing for detailed analysis and comparison of specific components.

str:Code.com:Name: By ministry
str:Code.com:Description: This indicates that data is organized or categorized according to different government ministries or departments, allowing for analysis of spending, performance, or other metrics within specific areas of government responsibility.

str:Code.com:Name: Comparative advantage
str:Code.com:Description: Comparative advantage is a measure of the relative advantage or disadvantage a particular economy has in a certain class of goods (in this case, environmental goods), and can be used to evaluate export potential in that class of goods. A value greater than one indicates a relative advantage in environmental goods, while a value of less than one indicates a relative disadvantage. 1

str:Code.com:Name: Composition of difference between recommended and projected cyclically adjusted primary balance as a percent of potential GDP
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to a detailed breakdown of the factors contributing to the difference between the recommended and projected cyclically adjusted primary balance (a measure of fiscal sustainability) relative to a country's potential GDP. The composition would likely include factors such as government revenue, expenditure, and economic growth projections, allowing for analysis of the drivers of fiscal imbalances.

str:Code.com:Name: Compound annual growth rate (CAGR), over 10 years
str:Code.com:Description: This represents the year-over-year growth rate of an investment over a specified 10-year period, assuming profits were reinvested during that time. It's a way to smooth out the effects of volatility and see the average annual growth.

str:Code.com:Name: Compound annual growth rate (CAGR), over 5 years
str:Code.com:Description: This represents the year-over-year growth rate of an investment over a specified 5-year period, assuming profits were reinvested during that time.

str:Code.com:Name: Contribution to global GDP growth
str:Code.com:Description: This measures how much each country's GDP growth contributes to the overall growth of the global economy.

str:Code.com:Name: Contribution to growth rate, flow over stock, over 12 periods
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the impact of a particular flow variable on the growth rate of a stock variable over a 12-period timeframe. It essentially measures the long-term contribution of a flow to the growth of a stock.

str:Code.com:Name: Contribution to growth rate, flow over stock, over 16 periods
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the impact of a particular flow variable on the growth rate of a stock variable over a 16-period timeframe.

str:Code.com:Name: Contribution to growth rate, flow over stock, over 3 periods
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the impact of a particular flow variable on the growth rate of a stock variable over a 3-period timeframe.

str:Code.com:Name: Contribution to growth rate, flow over stock, over 4 periods
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the impact of a particular flow variable on the growth rate of a stock variable over a 4-period timeframe.

str:Code.com:Name: Contribution to growth rate, flow over stock, over 6 periods
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the impact of a particular flow variable on the growth rate of a stock variable over a 6-period timeframe.

str:Code.com:Name: Contribution to growth rate, flow over stock, period-over-period (PoP)
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the impact of a particular flow variable on the growth rate of a stock variable between two consecutive periods. For example, it might measure how much an increase in sales (flow) contributed to the growth of a company's assets (stock) in a given quarter.

str:Code.com:Name: Contribution to growth rate, over 1 year
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the amount by which a specific factor or component has influenced the overall growth of a variable over a 12-month period.

str:Code.com:Name: Contribution to growth rate, over 12 periods
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the amount by which a specific factor or component has influenced the overall growth of a variable over 12 periods. For example, it could measure how much technological innovation has contributed to the average annual growth rate of productivity over the past 12 years.

str:Code.com:Name: Contribution to growth rate, over 3 periods
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the amount by which a specific factor or component has influenced the overall growth of a variable over 3 periods.

str:Code.com:Name: Contribution to growth rate, over 4 periods
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the amount by which a specific factor or component has influenced the overall growth of a variable over 4 periods.

str:Code.com:Name: Contribution to growth rate, over 6 periods
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the amount by which a specific factor or component has influenced the overall growth of a variable over 6 periods.

str:Code.com:Name: Contribution to growth rate, period-over-period (PoP)
str:Code.com:Description: Contribution to growth rate, period on period" is a method of analysis that quantifies how much each component of a variable influences the change in its growth rate between two consecutive time periods. For example, if overall GDP growth increased from 2% to 3% between two quarters, this analysis would break down how much of that 1% increase was due to factors like consumer spending, investment, or government spending.

str:Code.com:Name: Contribution to real GDP growth
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to how much each component of a country's economy contributes to the overall change in Gross Domestic Product (GDP) over a specific period.

str:Code.com:Name: Contribution to world growth
str:Code.com:Description: It refers to the extent to which a specific country or region's economic activity influences the overall growth of the global economy.

str:Code.com:Name: Corresponding period
str:Code.com:Description: A specific time frame in a prior cycle (e.g., month, quarter, year) that occupies the same relative position as the current period being analyzed.

str:Code.com:Name: Corresponding period, previous year
str:Code.com:Description: A specific time frame in the immediately preceding calendar year that occupies the same relative position as the current period being analyzed. This allows for comparison between two periods with similar characteristics to isolate the impact of a specific factor or trend, specifically focusing on year-over-year changes.

str:Code.com:Name: Corresponding to fiscal year
str:Code.com:Description: Indicates that a specific event, transaction, or data point relates to a particular fiscal year. It's used to clarify the time frame being referenced, especially when it differs from the calendar year.

str:Code.com:Name: Cost, insurance, and freight Northwest Europe (CIF NWE)
str:Code.com:Description: CIF NWE (Cost, Insurance, and Freight Northwest Europe) is a pricing term used in the oil and petroleum industry. It indicates that the seller is responsible for the costs, insurance, and freight of delivering the product to a port in Northwest Europe. sumes responsibility for the goods once they are loaded onto the ship at the port of origin. NEW likely refers to a specific geographic region or port, but without further context, it's difficult to be certain.

str:Code.com:Name: Country weights for EA-16
str:Code.com:Description: The country weights for EA-16 represent the relative economic importance of each member country within the euro area at that time. EA-16 refers to the euro area as it existed before the accession of Slovakia in 2009.

str:Code.com:Name: Crypto shadow rate
str:Code.com:Description: This is a hypothetical interest rate that reflects the true cost of borrowing in the cryptocurrency market, taking into account factors such as collateralization requirements, platform fees, and market volatility. It is often used to assess the risk and profitability of cryptocurrency lending and borrowing activities.

str:Code.com:Name: Crypto shadow rate premium
str:Code.com:Description: This is the difference between the crypto shadow rate and a benchmark interest rate, such as the risk-free rate or the prevailing rate in traditional financial markets. It reflects the additional risk premium associated with lending or borrowing in the cryptocurrency market compared to traditional markets.

str:Code.com:Name: Cumulated sum, over 1 year
str:Code.com:Description: A cumulated sum over 1 year, also known as a cumulative sum or running total, is the total sum of a set of values added together over a 12-month period. Each new period's value is added to the sum of the previous periods, creating a running tally.

str:Code.com:Name: Cumulative
str:Code.com:Description: The progressive total of successive additions.

str:Code.com:Name: De-meaned
str:Code.com:Description: Denote the calculation to adjust by the mean.

str:Code.com:Name: Difference, over 1 year
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the change in a variable's value between two points in time exactly one year apart.

str:Code.com:Name: Differences, period on 4 periods, first order
str:Code.com:Description: This measures the change in a variable's value between the current period and the value four periods ago.

str:Code.com:Name: Differences, period-over-period (PoP), first order
str:Code.com:Description: This is the change in a variable's value between consecutive periods (e.g., month to month, quarter to quarter).

str:Code.com:Name: Differences, period-over-period (PoP), second order
str:Code.com:Description: This measures the change in the rate of change of a variable between consecutive periods. It's the difference between the first-order differences of two consecutive periods.

str:Code.com:Name: Domestic currency per capita
str:Code.com:Description: Domestic currency per capita is a measure of the amount of a country's domestic currency that each person would have if the total amount were divided equally among the population. It is calculated by dividing the total amount of domestic currency in circulation by the country's population.

str:Code.com:Name: Domestic currency per capita, Percent change
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the rate at which the average income per person in a country, measured in its local currency, is increasing or decreasing over a specific period.

str:Code.com:Name: Domestic currency percent change
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the percentage change in the value of a country's domestic currency compared to another currency or a basket of currencies. It measures the appreciation or depreciation of the domestic currency over a specified period of time. The percentage change can be calculated based on daily, weekly, monthly, or yearly fluctuations.

str:Code.com:Name: Emissions intensities
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the amount of greenhouse gas emissions (usually measured in carbon dioxide equivalents) released per unit of economic output or activity. It is often used to assess the environmental impact of different industries, countries, or production processes. Lower emissions intensities generally indicate greater efficiency and lower environmental impact.

str:Code.com:Name: Emissions intensities (normalized)
str:Code.com:Description: This likely refers to emissions intensities that have been adjusted or standardized to account for differences in factors such as economic structure, technology, or population size. Normalization allows for more meaningful comparisons of emissions intensities across different entities or time periods by removing the influence of these factors.

str:Code.com:Name: Emissions multipliers
str:Code.com:Description: These are factors used to convert emissions of different greenhouse gases into carbon dioxide equivalents based on their global warming potential (GWP). This allows for the aggregation of different greenhouse gas emissions into a single metric for easier comparison and analysis.

str:Code.com:Name: Emissions multipliers (normalized)
str:Code.com:Description: This likely refers to emissions multipliers that have been adjusted or standardized in some way, possibly to account for changes in GWP estimates over time or to align with specific reporting requirements.

str:Code.com:Name: End of year (EoY)
str:Code.com:Description: The last day of a company's financial year (fiscal year-end) or the last day of the calendar year (December 31st). It is a key reference point for financial reporting and analysis.

str:Code.com:Name: End-of-period (EoP)
str:Code.com:Description: Refers to the end of any specific period, such as a quarter, month, or week. It marks the point at which economic or financial data or indexes are aggregated and/or analyzed.

str:Code.com:Name: Europe aggregate
str:Code.com:Description: It refers to a compilation or consolidation of economic data across different European countries or regions.

str:Code.com:Name: Fixed weighted imports by total commodity
str:Code.com:Description: Weights commodities in an import index based on their share of the total value of commodity imports, using historical fixed weights.

str:Code.com:Name: Fixed weighted imports to GDP
str:Code.com:Description: Weights individual commodities in an import index based on their share of the country's GDP, using historical fixed weights.

str:Code.com:Name: Floating rate and up to 1 year
str:Code.com:Description: This describes a type of interest rate that is not fixed but instead changes periodically based on a benchmark or reference rate, such as the LIBOR (London Interbank Offered Rate). The "up to 1 year" part likely refers to the maturity or reset period of the floating rate, meaning the rate is adjusted at least once a year, if not more frequently.

str:Code.com:Name: Forecast error, period t
str:Code.com:Description: The difference between the forecasted value and the actual value in a specific time period (t). This is a measure of how accurate a forecast was.

str:Code.com:Name: Forecast error, period t+1
str:Code.com:Description: The difference between the forecasted value and the actual value in the period immediately following t.

str:Code.com:Name: Forecast error, period t+2
str:Code.com:Description: The difference between the forecasted value and the actual value two periods after t.

str:Code.com:Name: Forecast error, period t+3
str:Code.com:Description: The difference between the forecasted value and the actual value three periods after t.

str:Code.com:Name: GDP market exchange rates weighed aggregate
str:Code.com:Description: GDP, market exchange rates weighted aggregate" is a measure of the combined economic output of multiple countries, where each country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is: 1. Converted to a common currency (usually US dollars) using prevailing market exchange rates. 2. Weighted according to its relative economic size, giving larger economies more influence. 3. Summed together to create an overall indicator of global economic activity.

str:Code.com:Name: GDP market exchange rates weighed aggregate, percent change
str:Code.com:Description: It represents the percentage change in the combined GDP of a group of countries, where each country's GDP is converted to a common currency (usually US dollars) using market exchange rates and then weighted based on its economic importance.

str:Code.com:Name: Growth rate period-over-period (PoP), over 4-period cumulated sum
str:Code.com:Description: The cumulative percentage change in a metric over four consecutive periods, compared to the starting value.

str:Code.com:Name: Growth rate, flow over stock, over 1 year
str:Code.com:Description: The annualized growth rate of a flow variable (e.g., sales, income) relative to a stock variable (e.g., assets, equity) over 1 year. This measures how quickly a flow variable is growing relative to a stock variable over a year, expressed as an annualized rate.

str:Code.com:Name: Growth rate, flow over stock, over 12 periods
str:Code.com:Description: The annualized growth rate of a flow variable (e.g., sales, income) relative to a stock variable (e.g., assets, equity) over 12 periods. This provides a standardized annual growth rate, making it easier to compare growth across different time frames or variables.

str:Code.com:Name: Growth rate, flow over stock, over 3 periods
str:Code.com:Description: The annualized growth rate of a flow variable (e.g., sales, income) relative to a stock variable (e.g., assets, equity) over 3 periods.

str:Code.com:Name: Growth rate, flow over stock, over 4 periods
str:Code.com:Description: The annualized growth rate of a flow variable (e.g., sales, income) relative to a stock variable (e.g., assets, equity) over 4 periods.

str:Code.com:Name: Growth rate, flow over stock, over 6 periods
str:Code.com:Description: The annualized growth rate of a flow variable (e.g., sales, income) relative to a stock variable (e.g., assets, equity) over 6 periods.

str:Code.com:Name: Growth rate, flow over stock, period-over-period (PoP)
str:Code.com:Description: The period-on-period growth rate of the flow variable divided by the stock variable in the current period. This measures how quickly a flow variable (like sales or income) is growing relative to a stock variable (like assets or equity) over a single period.

str:Code.com:Name: Growth rate, over 1 year
str:Code.com:Description: This means the percentage change in a variable over a one-year period.

str:Code.com:Name: Growth rate, over 1 year, based on 12-period average
str:Code.com:Description: The annual growth rate calculated by comparing the current value to the average value over the past 12 periods. This smooths out short-term fluctuations and provides a more stable measure of growth over the year.

str:Code.com:Name: Growth rate, over 1 year, based on 3-period average
str:Code.com:Description: The annual growth rate calculated by comparing the current value to the average value over the past 3 periods.

str:Code.com:Name: Growth rate, over 10 periods
str:Code.com:Description: This simply means the percentage change in a variable over ten consecutive periods. The periods could be years, quarters, months, etc., depending on the context.

str:Code.com:Name: Growth rate, over 12 periods
str:Code.com:Description: This means the percentage change in a variable over twelve consecutive periods.

str:Code.com:Name: Growth rate, over 3 periods
str:Code.com:Description: This means the percentage change in a variable over three consecutive periods.

str:Code.com:Name: Growth rate, over 3 years
str:Code.com:Description: This means the percentage change in a variable over a three-year period.

str:Code.com:Name: Growth rate, over 4 periods
str:Code.com:Description: This means the percentage change in a variable over four consecutive periods.

str:Code.com:Name: Growth rate, over 4 years
str:Code.com:Description: This means the percentage change in a variable over a four-year period.

str:Code.com:Name: Growth rate, over 6 periods
str:Code.com:Description: This means the percentage change in a variable over six consecutive periods.

str:Code.com:Name: Growth rate, over reference year
str:Code.com:Description: This means the percentage change in a variable compared to its value in a specific reference year. This is often used to track long-term trends or to compare growth relative to a significant base year.

str:Code.com:Name: Growth rate, period-over-period (PoP)
str:Code.com:Description: The percentage change in a metric (e.g., sales, GDP, stock price) from one period to the next. The periods could be months, quarters, or years.

str:Code.com:Name: Herfindahl index
str:Code.com:Description: The Herfindahl-Hirschman Index (HHI) is a commonly used measure of market concentration. It is calculated by squaring the market share of each firm competing in a market and then summing the resulting numbers. The HHI can range from 0 to 10,000. A market with an HHI of less than 1,500 is considered to be a competitive marketplace, an HHI of 1,500 to 2,500 to be a moderately concentrated marketplace, and an HHI of 2,500 or greater to be a highly concentrated marketplace.

str:Code.com:Name: Hodrick-Prescott filter
str:Code.com:Description: The Hodrick-Prescott (HP) filter is a mathematical tool used to separate a time series into its trend and cyclical components. It is often used in macroeconomics to analyze business cycles and identify long-term trends in economic data.

str:Code.com:Name: Referenced to 2000 U.S. dollars
str:Code.com:Description: Adjusted monetary value for inflation, reflecting worth in the year 2000.

str:Code.com:Name: Referenced to 2000 U.S. dollars, per capita
str:Code.com:Description: Adjusted average monetary value per person for inflation, reflecting worth in the year 2000.

str:Code.com:Name: In months of next year's imports of goods and services
str:Code.com:Description: It refers to a metric expressing a country's foreign exchange reserves (typically held by its central bank) relative to the estimated value of its imports in the following year. It indicates how many months of imports the country could afford if its reserves remained unchanged and its import levels were projected forward. This is a measure of a country's external liquidity and its ability to withstand shocks to its balance of payments.

str:Code.com:Name: Index computation
str:Code.com:Description: Index computation is the process of calculating a derived variable that represents the relative change in a group of related items over time or across different contexts. This process often involves complex transformations using multiple input variables, which are combined and weighted according to a specific formula or methodology. The resulting index provides a simplified and standardized way to track changes in the underlying variables over time or across different situations.

str:Code.com:Name: Index, annualized
str:Code.com:Description: The annualized change of an index measures the percentage change in the index's value over a year, assuming the same rate of change continues throughout the year. This is often used to compare the performance of indices over different time periods or to annualize growth rates that are measured over shorter periods.

str:Code.com:Name: Index, end-of-period (EoP)
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the value of an index at the end of a specific period, such as a day, month, quarter, or year. It provides a snapshot of the index's level at a particular point in time, often used for tracking and comparing performance over time.

str:Code.com:Name: Index, not seasonally adjusted (NSA)
str:Code.com:Description: An index that reflects the actual, raw data without any adjustments made for predictable seasonal fluctuations (e.g., increased retail sales during the holiday season). This provides a more direct view of the underlying trend but may be more volatile due to seasonal influences.

str:Code.com:Name: Index, percent change
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the percentage change in the value of an index over a specific period. It measures how much the index has increased or decreased relative to its value at the beginning of the period.

str:Code.com:Name: Index, period average
str:Code.com:Description: The arithmetic mean (average) of an index's values over a specified time period, such as a month, quarter, or year. This average smooths out short-term fluctuations and provides a more representative picture of the index's overall trend during that period.

str:Code.com:Name: Index, seasonally adjusted (SA)
str:Code.com:Description: An index that has been modified to remove the effects of recurring seasonal patterns. This allows for easier comparison of values across different time periods, as it isolates underlying trends from predictable fluctuations caused by seasonal factors.

str:Code.com:Name: Index, weighted average of the partner countries' data, weighted by the partner countries' shares in reporting country's exports
str:Code.com:Description: This is a composite index that measures the overall performance or change of a specific indicator (e.g., inflation rate, GDP growth) among a country's export partners. It is calculated by taking a weighted average of the indicator's values in each partner country, where the weights are the respective shares of each partner in the reporting country's total exports.

str:Code.com:Name: Index, weighted average of the partner countries' data, weighted by the partner countries' shares in reporting country's imports
str:Code.com:Description: This index measures the overall performance or change of a specific indicator among a country's import partners. Calculation: It is calculated by taking a weighted average of the indicator's values in each partner country, where the weights are the respective shares of each partner in the reporting country's total imports.

str:Code.com:Name: Index, weighted by exports
str:Code.com:Description: An index weighted by exports is a statistical measure that tracks the combined performance of a group of export-related variables, with each variable's contribution to the overall index being determined by its relative importance in the total export value. This is often used to analyze the impact of changes in export prices or volumes on the overall economy.

str:Code.com:Name: Index, weighted by imports
str:Code.com:Description: This is a statistical measure that tracks the combined performance or trends of a group of import-related variables, with each variable's contribution to the overall index determined by its relative importance in the total import value. This is often used to analyze the impact of changes in import prices or volumes on the overall economy.

str:Code.com:Name: Indexed to a reference period
str:Code.com:Description: The process of adjusting a value (e.g., wage, price, or index) based on changes in a specific reference point, usually a price index. This helps account for inflation or other economic factors, allowing for a fairer comparison over time. For example, wages might be indexed to the consumer price index (CPI) to ensure that their purchasing power remains constant despite inflation.

str:Code.com:Name: Individual commodities weighted by ratio of exports to GDP
str:Code.com:Description: A method of weighting individual commodities in an index based on the proportion of their export value relative to the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).

str:Code.com:Name: Individual commodities weighted by ratio of exports to GDP, historical fixed weights
str:Code.com:Description: It weights individual commodities in an export index based on their share of the country's GDP.

str:Code.com:Name: Individual commodities weighted by ratio of exports to GDP, historical rolling weights
str:Code.com:Description: It weights individual commodities in an export index based on their share of the country's GDP.

str:Code.com:Name: Individual commodities weighted by ratio of exports to GDP, recent fixed weights
str:Code.com:Description: It weights individual commodities in an export index based on their share of the country's GDP.

str:Code.com:Name: Individual commodities weighted by ratio of exports to GDP, recent rolling weights
str:Code.com:Description: It weights individual commodities in an export index based on their share of the country's GDP.

str:Code.com:Name: Individual commodities weighted by ratio of exports to total commodity exports
str:Code.com:Description: A method of weighting individual commodities in an export index based on their share of the total value of commodity exports.

str:Code.com:Name: Individual commodities weighted by ratio of exports to total commodity exports, historical fixed weights
str:Code.com:Description: It weights commodities in an export index based on their share of the total value of commodity exports.

str:Code.com:Name: Individual commodities weighted by ratio of exports to total commodity exports, historical rolling weights
str:Code.com:Description: It weights commodities in an export index based on their share of the total value of commodity exports.

str:Code.com:Name: Individual commodities weighted by ratio of exports to total commodity exports, recent fixed weights
str:Code.com:Description: It weights commodities in an export index based on their share of the total value of commodity exports.

str:Code.com:Name: Individual commodities weighted by ratio of exports to total commodity exports, recent rolling weights
str:Code.com:Description: It weights commodities in an export index based on their share of the total value of commodity exports.

str:Code.com:Name: Individual commodities weighted by ratio of imports to total commodity imports, historical rolling weights
str:Code.com:Description: It weights commodities in an import index based on their share of the total value of commodity imports.

str:Code.com:Name: Individual commodities weighted by ratio of imports to total commodity imports, recent fixed weights
str:Code.com:Description: It weights commodities in an import index based on their share of the total value of commodity imports.

str:Code.com:Name: Individual commodities weighted by ratio of imports to total commodity imports, recent rolling weights
str:Code.com:Description: It weights commodities in an import index based on their share of the total value of commodity imports.

str:Code.com:Name: Individual commodities weighted by ratio of net exports to GDP
str:Code.com:Description: This weights commodities based on their net export value (exports minus imports) relative to GDP. It focuses on commodities where the country has a trade surplus or deficit, indicating the net impact of these commodities on the economy.

str:Code.com:Name: Individual commodities weighted by ratio of net exports to GDP, historical fixed weights
str:Code.com:Description: This weights commodities based on their net export value (exports minus imports) relative to GDP. It focuses on commodities where the country has a trade surplus or deficit, indicating the net impact of these commodities on the economy.

str:Code.com:Name: Individual commodities weighted by ratio of net exports to GDP, historical rolling weights
str:Code.com:Description: This weights commodities based on their net export value (exports minus imports) relative to GDP. It focuses on commodities where the country has a trade surplus or deficit, indicating the net impact of these commodities on the economy.

str:Code.com:Name: Individual commodities weighted by ratio of net exports to GDP, recent fixed weights
str:Code.com:Description: This weights commodities based on their net export value (exports minus imports) relative to GDP. It focuses on commodities where the country has a trade surplus or deficit, indicating the net impact of these commodities on the economy.

str:Code.com:Name: Individual commodities weighted by ratio of net exports to GDP, recent rolling weights
str:Code.com:Description: This weights commodities based on their net export value (exports minus imports) relative to GDP. It focuses on commodities where the country has a trade surplus or deficit, indicating the net impact of these commodities on the economy.

str:Code.com:Name: Individual commodities weighted by ratio of net exports to total commodity trade
str:Code.com:Description: This weights commodities based on their net export value relative to the total value of commodity trade (exports plus imports)

str:Code.com:Name: Individual commodities weighted by ratio of net exports to total commodity trade, historical fixed weights
str:Code.com:Description: This weights commodities based on their net export value relative to the total value of commodity trade (exports plus imports)

str:Code.com:Name: Individual commodities weighted by ratio of net exports to total commodity trade, historical rolling weights
str:Code.com:Description: This weights commodities based on their net export value relative to the total value of commodity trade (exports plus imports)

str:Code.com:Name: Individual commodities weighted by ratio of net exports to total commodity trade, recent fixed weights
str:Code.com:Description: This weights commodities based on their net export value relative to the total value of commodity trade (exports plus imports)

str:Code.com:Name: Individual commodities weighted by ratio of net exports to total commodity trade, recent rolling weights
str:Code.com:Description: This weights commodities based on their net export value relative to the total value of commodity trade (exports plus imports)

str:Code.com:Name: Inflation target - lower range
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the minimum acceptable rate of inflation that a central bank or monetary authority aims to achieve over a specific period. The lower range of the inflation target is intended to avoid deflation or a significant slowdown in economic activity, ensuring price stability and economic growth.

str:Code.com:Name: Inflation target - single value
str:Code.com:Description: This is a specific rate of inflation that a central bank or monetary authority sets as its goal for a defined period. The single value target represents the ideal rate of inflation that balances the need to support economic growth while maintaining price stability.

str:Code.com:Name: Inflation target - upper value
str:Code.com:Description: This denotes the maximum acceptable rate of inflation that a central bank or monetary authority aims to prevent exceeding over a specific period. The upper value of the inflation target is set to avoid overheating the economy and excessive price increases, which can lead to economic instability and decreased purchasing power.

str:Code.com:Name: INR per kilogram
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to a price or cost expressed in Indian Rupees (INR) per kilogram of a specific good or commodity.

str:Code.com:Name: Natural log (GDP per capita)
str:Code.com:Description: This represents the natural logarithm of GDP per capita. GDP per capita is a measure of a country's economic output per person, calculated by dividing the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) by the population. Taking the natural log of this value is often done to make the data more suitable for statistical analysis, particularly when dealing with skewed distributions or exponential growth patterns.

str:Code.com:Name: Natural log (Service export sophistication)
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the natural logarithm of a measure of the sophistication or complexity of a country's service exports. Service export sophistication might be calculated based on factors such as the types of services exported, the technological intensity of those services, and the diversity of export markets. Taking the natural logarithm is often done to transform data and make it more suitable for statistical analysis, particularly when dealing with skewed distributions or large differences in scale.

str:Code.com:Name: Natural log (Service exports)
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the natural logarithm of the value of total service exports. Taking the natural logarithm is a mathematical transformation often used to stabilize variance, make data more normally distributed, or to deal with exponential growth patterns.

str:Code.com:Name: Measured as declines
str:Code.com:Description: This indicates that the unit of measurement for this variable represents the number or magnitude of declines observed in a particular phenomenon. For example, it might measure the number of job losses in a particular industry or the decline in biodiversity in a specific region.

str:Code.com:Name: MER (Management Expense Ratio) weighted
str:Code.com:Description: The term "MER weighted" typically refers to a weighted average calculation where the weights are based on the Management Expense Ratio (MER) of different investment funds or portfolios. The MER represents the annual operating expenses of a mutual fund, exchange-traded fund (ETF), or other investment, expressed as a percentage of the fund's average net asset value. MER weighted calculations are often used to compare the performance of different funds or portfolios after taking into account their expense ratios.

str:Code.com:Name: Metric tons of CO₂ emissions per $1 million USD of output
str:Code.com:Description: This measures the amount of carbon dioxide emissions produced for every $1 million of economic output generated. It is an indicator of the carbon intensity of an economy or industry, reflecting how efficiently resources are used and how much pollution is generated per unit of economic activity.

str:Code.com:Name: Monthly index, backdated, ECU (to 1989) and fixed euro conversion rate (from 1990) used for weights
str:Code.com:Description: A monthly economic index that has been calculated retroactively to include data from before the euro was introduced. Before 1990, the index uses the European Currency Unit (ECU) as the basis for calculations and weighting. From 1990 onwards, it uses a fixed euro conversion rate to maintain consistency with the earlier ECU-based data. This allows for long-term comparisons of economic trends even though the underlying currency changed.

str:Code.com:Name: Monthly index, backdated, fixed euro conversion rate used for weights
str:Code.com:Description: A monthly economic index that has been calculated retroactively. After 1990, the index transitions to using the euro, with a fixed conversion rate applied to ensure consistency with earlier data.

str:Code.com:Name: Monthly index, backdated, PPP exchange rates used for weights
str:Code.com:Description: A monthly index, backdated, using Purchasing Power Parity (PPP) exchange rates for weights, would serve as a historical measure of the relative value of a country's currency against others, adjusted for differences in purchasing power. PPP exchange rates take into account the relative cost of goods and services in different countries, providing a more accurate comparison of living standards and economic output than market exchange rates.

str:Code.com:Name: Month-over-month (MoM) percent change, end-of-period (EoP)
str:Code.com:Description: Month-over-month (MoM) percent change, end-of-period (EoP) refers to the percentage change in the value of a specific metric (e.g., sales, stock price, or economic indicator) from the end of one month to the end of the next month. This is a common way to track short-term trends and volatility in data.

str:Code.com:Name: Months of imports of goods and services
str:Code.com:Description: This is a measure of a country's foreign exchange reserves relative to its import levels. It indicates how many months of imports could be financed with the current level of reserves. A higher value indicates a greater ability to withstand external shocks and maintain import flows even in times of economic difficulty.

str:Code.com:Name: Natural log difference between 2012 and 2000 for a given country's total service exports
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the difference in the natural logarithms of a country's total service exports in 2012 and 2000. Taking the natural log of values is often done to transform data and make it more suitable for statistical analysis, particularly when dealing with exponential growth or large differences in scale. The difference in natural logs provides a measure of the relative change in service exports between the two years.

str:Code.com:Name: Natural log of a country's service exports in 2000
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the natural logarithm of the value of a country's total service exports in the year 2000. Taking the natural log of a value is a mathematical transformation that is often used to stabilize variance, make data more normally distributed, or to deal with exponential growth patterns.

str:Code.com:Name: Net change
str:Code.com:Description: Net change refers to the overall difference between the final value and the initial value of a quantity over a specific period of time, taking into account both increases and decreases. It represents the overall effect of all changes, regardless of their direction.

str:Code.com:Name: Not applicable
str:Code.com:Description: No transformations applied

str:Code.com:Name: Number of numerical rules (national and supranational), all rules
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the count of numerical rules that are currently in effect and being enforced, including both those set at the national level (by individual countries) and those established supranationally (by international organizations or agreements).

str:Code.com:Name: Number of numerical rules (national and supranational), rules in place
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the count of numerical rules that are currently in effect and being enforced, including both those set at the national level (by individual countries) and those established supranationally (by international organizations or agreements). This excludes rules that have been proposed but not yet implemented, or those that have been repealed.

str:Code.com:Name: Number of numerical rules (national and supranational), strictly national
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the count of numerical rules that are exclusively set at the national level by individual countries and do not originate from supranational agreements or organizations.

str:Code.com:Name: Number of tourist nights, previous period percent change
str:Code.com:Description: The percentage change in the number of tourist nights compared to the previous period.

str:Code.com:Name: Number of tourist nights, year-over-year (YOY) percent change
str:Code.com:Description: The percentage change in the number of tourist nights compared to the same period in the previous year.

str:Code.com:Name: Other financial corporations, total assets to gross domestic product (GDP)
str:Code.com:Description: The ratio of other financial corporations' total assets to gross domestic product (GDP). This measures the size of the assets held by financial institutions other than banks (e.g., insurance companies, investment funds) relative to the overall size of the economy.

str:Code.com:Name: Overlap
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to a period where existing and new series (e.g., Consumer Price Index) are compiled in parallel to allow the two to be linked. It's a methodological construct to facilitate linking and ensure a smooth transition between different versions or methodologies of data collection.

str:Code.com:Name: Partner trade weighted index
str:Code.com:Description: Trade-weighted average value for a specific variable, reflecting the relative importance of trade partners.

str:Code.com:Name: Partner trade weighted index, adjusted by relative consumer prices
str:Code.com:Description: Trade-weighted index adjusted for inflation differences between the country and its trade partners.

str:Code.com:Name: Partner trade weighted index, adjusted by relative unit labor costs
str:Code.com:Description: Trade-weighted index adjusted for relative changes in labor costs between the country and its trade partners.

str:Code.com:Name: Partner trade weighted, YOY, period average, percent change
str:Code.com:Description: YOY percentage change in the trade-weighted average for a specific variable.

str:Code.com:Name: Partner trade weighted, YOY, period average, percent change, adjusted by relative consumer prices
str:Code.com:Description: YOY percent change, considering inflation-adjusted trade weights.

str:Code.com:Name: Pension funds, assets to gross domestic product (GDP)
str:Code.com:Description: This ratio measures the total assets held by pension funds in a country relative to its GDP. Pension funds are financial institutions that collect contributions from workers and invest them to provide retirement income. This ratio indicates the relative importance of pension fund assets within the overall economy.

str:Code.com:Name: Per 1,000 adults
str:Code.com:Description: Value expressed per 1,000 adults.

str:Code.com:Name: Per 1,000 female adults
str:Code.com:Description: Value expressed per 1,000 female adults.

str:Code.com:Name: Per 1,000 square km
str:Code.com:Description: Value expressed per 1,000 square kilometers.

str:Code.com:Name: Per 1,000 male adults
str:Code.com:Description: Value expressed per 1,000 male adults.

str:Code.com:Name: Per 100,000 adults
str:Code.com:Description: This means that the value is expressed per unit of 100,000 adults. This is often used for health or demographic statistics, such as mortality rates or disease prevalence rates.

str:Code.com:Name: Per capita
str:Code.com:Description: Per capita is a Latin term that means "for each head" or "per person." It is often used in economic and statistical analysis to compare data across populations of different sizes. When a figure is given per capita, it means the average amount per person. For example, GDP per capita is a measure of a country's economic output per person.

str:Code.com:Name: Per capita, percent change
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the percentage increase or decrease in a particular value when calculated on a per-person basis. For example, it could measure the percentage change in income per capita or the percentage change in carbon dioxide emissions per capita.

str:Code.com:Name: Per capita, purchasing power parity (PPP) international dollar
str:Code.com:Description: Average income or economic output per person adjusted for cost-of-living differences between countries, expressed in international dollars.

str:Code.com:Name: Per capita, ratio
str:Code.com:Description: A ratio that is calculated on a per-person basis. This could include ratios such as the number of doctors per capita, the number of hospital beds per capita, or the amount of government debt per capita.

str:Code.com:Name: Per ounce of gold, end-of-period (EoP), rate
str:Code.com:Description: This likely refers to the price or exchange rate of gold quoted in a specific currency (e.g., US dollars, euros) at the end of a trading period, such as the end of a day, month, or year.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent change
str:Code.com:Description: This measures the relative change in a value over time, expressed as a percentage. It is calculated as the difference between the new value and the old value, divided by the old value, and multiplied by 100. 1

str:Code.com:Name: Percent change US dollar
str:Code.com:Description: Percent change in a monetary value denominated in US dollars.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent change, corresponding period, previous year
str:Code.com:Description: This measures the relative change in a value over time, expressed as a percentage between a particular time period in the current year and the same time period in the previous year. This is often used to track year-over-year growth or changes in economic indicators.

str:Code.com:Name: End-of-period (EoP), percent change
str:Code.com:Description: This focuses on the change between the value at the beginning of a period and the value at the end of that period. The period could be a day, month, quarter, year, etc. This is often used to track changes in financial or economic indicators over specific periods.

str:Code.com:Name: End-of-period (EoP), index, percent change
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the percentage change in the value of an index between the beginning and end of a specific period. The period could be a day, month, quarter, or year. This is often used to track the performance of stock market indices or other financial indicators over specific periods.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent change, impact
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the percentage change in a value, along with an assessment of the impact or significance of this change. The impact might be evaluated in terms of its economic, social, or environmental consequences.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent change, period average
str:Code.com:Description: This calculates the change relative to the average value over the entire period, not just the starting point. This is often used when the data fluctuates significantly within the period, and the average provides a more representative value for comparison.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent change, period average, index
str:Code.com:Description: The percentage change in the average value of an index (e.g., stock market index, consumer price index) over a specific period compared to a reference value, often the initial value or the average value of a previous period.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent change, period average, weighted average of the partner countries' data weighted by the partner countries' shares in reporting country's exports
str:Code.com:Description: The average percentage change over a specific period in a weighted average of a variable for a group of a country's trading partners, where the weights are based on their respective shares in the reporting country's total exports. This gives more weight to the changes in countries that are more important export destinations.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent change, period average, weighted average of the partner countries' data weighted by the partner countries' shares in reporting country's imports
str:Code.com:Description: The average percentage change over a specific period in a weighted average of a variable for a group of a country's trading partners, where the weights are based on their respective shares in the reporting country's total imports. This gives more weight to the changes in countries that are more important trading partners.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent change, period average, weighted by exports
str:Code.com:Description: This is used to analyze the change in export values over a specific period, where the average export value is calculated by weighting different export categories based on their relative importance. This gives more weight to the changes in export categories that are more significant in the country's overall export structure.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent change, period average, weighted by imports
str:Code.com:Description: This is used to analyze the change in import values over a specific period, where the average import value is calculated by weighting different import categories based on their relative importance. This gives more weight to the changes in import categories that are more significant in the country's overall import structure.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent change, previous period in the external trade balance as a percent of GDP
str:Code.com:Description: The percentage change from the previous period in the difference between the value of a country's exports and imports of goods and services, relative to its Gross Domestic Product (GDP). This measures the change in the trade balance as a share of the economy.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent change, simple average
str:Code.com:Description: The percentage change calculated by taking the simple average of percentage changes for individual data points within a set. This is a straightforward way to calculate the average percentage change, but it may be influenced by outliers.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent change, weight
str:Code.com:Description: The percentage change in the weight assigned to a particular variable in a weighted average or index. This reflects how the relative importance of different components in the calculation has changed over time.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent change, weighted average of the partner countries' data weighted by the partner countries' shares in reporting country's exports
str:Code.com:Description: The percentage change in a specific economic variable (e.g., consumer prices, unit labor costs) for a group of a country's trading partners, weighted by the share of each partner in the reporting country's total exports. This gives more weight to the changes in countries that are more important export destinations.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent change, weighted average of the partner countries' data weighted by the partner countries' shares in reporting country's imports
str:Code.com:Description: The percentage change in a specific economic variable (e.g., consumer prices, unit labor costs) for a group of a country's trading partners, weighted by the share of each partner in the reporting country's total imports. This gives more weight to the changes in countries that are more important trading partners.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent change, weighted by exports
str:Code.com:Description: This is a metric used to analyze the change in export values over a specific period, where the percentage change is calculated for a weighted average of different export categories, with the weights based on their relative importance in the country's overall export structure.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent change, weighted by imports
str:Code.com:Description: This is a metric used to analyze the change in import values over a specific period, where the percentage change is calculated for a weighted average of different import categories, with the weights based on their relative importance in the country's overall import structure.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent change, yearly average
str:Code.com:Description: The average rate at which something increases or decreases over a period of years. This is often used to track long-term trends or to compare growth rates across different periods.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent difference from baseline (FSGM scenario)
str:Code.com:Description: In a Financial Sector General Model (FSGM) scenario, this refers to the percentage difference in a specific variable or outcome between a baseline scenario (often a "business as usual" scenario) and a stress-test scenario (e.g., a severe economic downturn). This is used to assess the impact of different economic conditions or policy changes on the financial sector.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent difference in scenario (data from modeling unit)
str:Code.com:Description: The percent difference in scenario (data from modeling unit) refers to the relative change between two values obtained from a modeling exercise, usually expressed as a percentage. These values often represent different scenarios or outcomes within the model, such as the difference in GDP growth between a baseline scenario and a policy intervention scenario.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of
str:Code.com:Description: The term "percent of" means a part per hundred of a whole. It's a way of expressing a fraction or a proportion in terms of hundredths. For example, 20% means 20 out of every 100.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of advanced economies excluding euro partners, multi-year average
str:Code.com:Description: This represents the average share, over multiple years, of a specific variable (e.g., GDP, trade, investment) attributed to advanced economies that are not part of the Eurozone. This excludes countries that use the euro as their currency.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of advanced economies, multi-year average
str:Code.com:Description: This represents the average share or proportion of a specific variable (e.g., GDP, trade, investment) attributed to advanced economies over a defined period of multiple years. It is usually calculated as the simple arithmetic mean of the variable's percentage values for each year in the specified period.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of SDR Allocation
str:Code.com:Description: This indicator calculates SDR Holdings as a percent of SDR Allocation.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of banking system assets
str:Code.com:Description: Percent of banking system assets refers to the proportion of total banking system assets relative to a specified baseline, often used to indicate the size or significance of a banking sector in the economy.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of broad money
str:Code.com:Description: Refers to the percentage of a country's broad money supply relative to its Gross Domestic Product (GDP).

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of CO2 emissions in total value added
str:Code.com:Description: The share of CO2 emissions expressed as a percentage of the total value added in an economy.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of commodity-based goods trade
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the proportion of a country's total trade (either imports or exports, or both) that consists of commodities.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of current account transactions
str:Code.com:Description: Percent of current account transactions refers to the proportion of a country's total international transactions that fall under the current account of its balance of payments.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of direct investment positions
str:Code.com:Description: Percent of direct investment positions indicates the proportion of a country's direct investments relative to its GDP or another reference metric.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of euro partners, multi-year average
str:Code.com:Description: It represents the average share or proportion of a specific variable attributed to countries within the Eurozone over a defined period of multiple years.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of Europe, multi-year average
str:Code.com:Description: It represents the average share or proportion of a specific variable attributed to European countries over a defined period of multiple years.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of exports
str:Code.com:Description: Indicates the proportion of a specific economic variable relative to total exports.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of exports of goods and services
str:Code.com:Description: Base concept expressed as a ratio to Exports of Goods and Services (BXGS).

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of exports of goods and services, median
str:Code.com:Description: Base concept expressed as a ratio to Exports of Goods and Services (BXGS).

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of external financing
str:Code.com:Description: This indicates the proportion of external financing relative to a specified baseline, such as total financing needs or GDP.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of final domestic demand
str:Code.com:Description: Represents a particular economic measure as a percentage of the final domestic demand in an economy.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of fiscal year GDP
str:Code.com:Description: Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country during its fiscal year, defined as the specific 12-month period a government uses for its budgeting and accounting purposes.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of fiscal year GDP in US dollar
str:Code.com:Description: Percent of fiscal year GDP in US dollar represents the share of GDP for a fiscal year expressed in US dollars.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of fiscal year GDP in US dollar, percent of GDP
str:Code.com:Description: Percent of fiscal year GDP in US dollar, expressed as a percentage of GDP.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of fiscal year GDP, impact
str:Code.com:Description: Represents the impact of a specific variable as a percentage of fiscal year GDP.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of GDP
str:Code.com:Description: Value expressed as a percent of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of a country.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of GDP from previous period
str:Code.com:Description: Measures the percentage change in GDP compared to the previous period.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of GDP in US dollars
str:Code.com:Description: Value expressed as a percent of the GDP of a country denominated in US dollars.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of GDP in US dollars, impact
str:Code.com:Description: Indicates the impact of a variable expressed as a percentage of GDP in US dollars.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of GDP per capita
str:Code.com:Description: Indicates a specific variable as a percentage of GDP per capita.

str:Code.com:Name: Ratio of this level of government's spending to total general government spending
str:Code.com:Description: Ratio of one level of government's spending to total general government spending.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of GNP
str:Code.com:Description: Value expressed as a percent of Gross National Product (GNP).

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of government revenue
str:Code.com:Description: Indicates a specific variable as a percentage of government revenue.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of gross capital account transactions
str:Code.com:Description: Indicates the percentage of a country's total capital account transactions relative to GDP or another metric.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of gross current transactions
str:Code.com:Description: Represents the percentage of a country's total current account transactions relative to GDP or another metric.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of gross current transfers
str:Code.com:Description: Indicates the percentage of a country's total current transfers relative to GDP or another relevant economic indicator.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of gross external debt
str:Code.com:Description: Indicates the proportion of gross external debt relative to GDP.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of gross goods transactions
str:Code.com:Description: Shows the percentage of a country's total trade in goods relative to GDP or another metric.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of gross income transactions
str:Code.com:Description: Refers to the percentage of a country's total primary income transactions relative to GDP or another metric.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of gross services transactions
str:Code.com:Description: Represents the percentage of a country's total trade in services relative to GDP or another metric.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of import type
str:Code.com:Description: Proportion of total imports that belong to a specific category or type.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of imports
str:Code.com:Description: Indicates the proportion of imports relative to a specific baseline.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of imports of goods and services
str:Code.com:Description: Total value of imported goods and services as a percentage of GDP.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of labor force
str:Code.com:Description: Represents the proportion of a specific group within the total labor force of a country.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of net external debt
str:Code.com:Description: Total external debt minus external assets, expressed as a percentage of GDP.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of non-financial corporation borrowers with commercial banks
str:Code.com:Description: Total deposits by non-financial corporations as a percentage of total deposits in commercial banks.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of non-financial corporation depositors with commercial banks
str:Code.com:Description: Number of non-financial corporations with deposit accounts as a percentage of the total number of deposit accounts.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of nonfinancial corporation loan accounts with commercial banks
str:Code.com:Description: Loan accounts held by non-financial corporations as a percentage of the total number of loan accounts.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of non-oil GDP
str:Code.com:Description: Value expressed as a percent of GDP originating from sectors other than the oil industry.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of own revenue
str:Code.com:Description: Refers to expenses or specific variables as a percentage of total own revenue generated.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of own spending
str:Code.com:Description: Indicates the proportion of specific budget categories within total spending.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of potential fiscal year GDP
str:Code.com:Description: Represents a specific variable as a percentage of the potential Gross Domestic Product (GDP) for a fiscal year.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of potential fiscal year GDP
str:Code.com:Description: Represents potential GDP for the fiscal year as a percentage.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of potential GDP
str:Code.com:Description: Value expressed as a percentage of potential GDP.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of potential GDP in nominal national currency, percent of GDP
str:Code.com:Description: Represents potential GDP in nominal national currency, expressed as a percentage of GDP.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of quota
str:Code.com:Description: Refers to the percent of IMF Quota utilized or represented.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of the regional groups
str:Code.com:Description: Metric expressing the share or proportion of a specific variable attributed to different regional groupings of countries.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of total
str:Code.com:Description: The proportion or share that a specific value or category represents within a larger whole.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of total allocated foreign exchange reserves
str:Code.com:Description: The percent of total allocated foreign exchange reserves refers to the proportion of a country's or institution's official foreign currency holdings that are held in a specific currency. This is often used to analyze the currency composition of foreign exchange reserves and assess the diversification of these holdings.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of total external debt
str:Code.com:Description: The total amount of a country's external debt (owed to foreign lenders), expressed as a percentage of its GDP.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of total nonfuel
str:Code.com:Description: The share of a specific item or category within the total amount of that item or category, excluding any components related to fuel or energy.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of total outlays
str:Code.com:Description: The share of a specific expenditure item or category within the total amount of all outlays or expenditures.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of world
str:Code.com:Description: The share of a particular indicator or variable that a specific country or region represents in the global total.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of world aggregate, multi-year average
str:Code.com:Description: Average share of a particular indicator or variable that a specific country or region represents in the global total over multiple years.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent of world excluding Euro partners, multi-year average
str:Code.com:Description: Average share of a particular indicator or variable that a specific country or region represents in the global total, excluding Eurozone countries.

str:Code.com:Name: Percent per annum
str:Code.com:Description: Expresses an annual rate or percentage, often used in financial contexts.

str:Code.com:Name: End-of-period (EoP), percent per annum
str:Code.com:Description: Annual rate of change applied at the end of a period, such as a month or quarter.

str:Code.com:Name: Period average
str:Code.com:Description: This refers to the arithmetic mean (average) value of a data series calculated over a specified period, such as a month, quarter, or year. It provides a representative value for the entire period, smoothing out any short-term fluctuations.

str:Code.com:Name: Period average, calendar
str:Code.com:Description: The average value of a data series over a specific period within a calendar year, such as a month, quarter, or a custom period.

str:Code.com:Name: Period average, index
str:Code.com:Description: The period average index refers to the mean value of an index (e.g., price index, exchange rate index) calculated over a specific period of time, such as a month, quarter, or year. This average is calculated by summing the index values for each individual time point within the specified period and then dividing by the number of observations.

str:Code.com:Name: Period average, index, weighted average of the partner countries' data weighted by the partner countries' shares in reporting country's exports
str:Code.com:Description: The average value of an index (e.g., price index, exchange rate index) for a group of a country's trading partners over a specific period, where the index values for each partner are weighted by their respective shares in the reporting country's total exports. This gives more weight to the index values of countries that are more important export destinations.

str:Code.com:Name: Period average, index, weighted average of the partner countries' data weighted by the partner countries' shares in reporting country's imports
str:Code.com:Description: The average value of an index (e.g., price index, exchange rate index) for a group of a country's trading partners over a specific period, where the index values for each partner are weighted by their respective shares in the reporting country's total imports. This gives more weight to the index values of countries that are more important trading partners.

str:Code.com:Name: Period average, index, weighted by exports
str:Code.com:Description: It is the average value of an index over a specific period, where the index itself is constructed by weighting different export categories according to their importance. This gives more weight to the export categories that are more significant in the country's overall export structure.

str:Code.com:Name: Period average, index, weighted by imports
